A combination of your patron's power and your own study have granted you the ability to cast spells. You use&reference[charisma] as your @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.sxKTtNPUrcDvMDFj.JournalEntryPage.arD4KLvgCPbi1Pl7]{spellcasting ability} for warlock spells, since your magic draws upon your connection to your patron's power.

Warlocks are &reference[knownspells]{known spellcasters}. The @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class.Item.whbTNYgkqWV8oGt3]{Warlock Progression Table} shows how many spell slots you have, as well as how many cantrips and spells you know. You can search the @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.vaLYevRxKe8mAvdE.JournalEntryPage.eIAPSko797Cjf0Yb]{list of warlock spells here}.

Spellcasting Focuses

You can use an arcane focus or component pouch as a @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.sxKTtNPUrcDvMDFj.JournalEntryPage.R25K8TvAPK3c4ywr]{spellcasting focus} for casting warlock spells.

For Multiclass Characters

If you are a multiclass character, your pact magic spell slots are combined additively with spell slots from any other class you may have. When you gain spell slots from either class, they are added to your total number of spell slots for that level. Note that Warlock is the only class that adds spell slots this way.
